Method Detail

daysBetween

public static int daysBetween(java.util.Calendar date1,
                              java.util.Calendar date2)
Returns the number of days between 2 dates. Will be negative if date2 < date1, 0 if both are the same day or positive otherwise

decimalDaysAdd

public static java.util.Calendar decimalDaysAdd(java.util.Calendar date1,
                                                java.math.BigDecimal augend)
inverse function of decimalDaysBetween: adds a BigDecimal number of days to a Calendar.

Parameters:
date1 - the date to which something is added
augend - the number of days which is added, as a BigDecimal. May be negative.
Returns:
null if one of the arguments is null, else the date + augend days.

decimalDaysBetween

public static java.math.BigDecimal decimalDaysBetween(java.util.Calendar date1,
                                                      java.util.Calendar date2)
Returns the number of days between 2 dates as a BigDecimal. Will be negative if date2 < date1, or positive otherwise.

equalizeTime

public static java.util.Calendar equalizeTime(java.util.Calendar toEqualize,
                                              java.util.Calendar source)
sets the time of the day of the first argument, so that it is equal to the time of the day of the second argument.

Parameters:
toEqualize - a Calendar, whose time will be equalized to the source's time of the day
source - the time of the day of this Calendar is taken.
Returns:
a new Calendar object, with the date equal to toEqualize, but the time of the date is equal to that of the source Calendar.

equals

public static boolean equals(java.util.Calendar cal1,
                             java.util.Calendar cal2,
                             int level)
compares two Calendars on a certain precision level.
For example, if you had the datetime of 12 Mar 2011 14:31:07.847, and a second datetime of 12 Mar 2011 14:31:11.734, they would evaluate as equal on the Calendar.MINUTE level and above. They would evaluate as not equal on levels Calendar.SECOND and Calendar.MILLISECOND.
Fields are rounded, so 12 Mar 2011 14:31:07.847 and 12 Mar 2011 14:31:08.123 would evaluate as equal on the Calendar.SECOND level.

Parameters:
cal1 - if null, returns false
cal2 - if null, returns false
level, - for example Calendar.MINUTE
Returns:
true if equal on this level, false if not.

getDayEnd

public static java.util.Calendar getDayEnd(java.util.Calendar date)
Returns a date at 23:59:59 of the given day

getEarliest

public static java.util.Calendar getEarliest(java.util.Calendar... dates)
a null proof method returning the earliest of any number of Calendars

Parameters:
dates - any null arguments are ignored. If all arguments are null just returns null.
Returns:
the earliest date of the arguments.

truncate

Truncates a date, handling null. Doesn't modify the Calendar parameter, returning a new modified instance

truncatePreviosDay

public static java.util.Calendar truncatePreviosDay(java.util.Calendar date)
Truncates a date and subtracts 1 day, handling null. Doesn't modify the Calendar parameter, returning a new modified instance
